Fields.DialogueText: Your guidance is really helping, Nellie. We've really been making headway against the Morganas.
It's nothing, Captain. The poison apple threw them off their guard, and when they got wise to that, I already had another plan waiting.
As I was saying, I'm impressed. If we keep up our momentum, we can roll up the Morgana fleet before they can make the world totally unrecognizeable.
And then what?
What do you mean? After we defeat the Morganas?
Yes, what happens when we defeat the bally BF and then we're just a big jumble of ships and folk from all over?

Fields.MenuText: Why don't we worry about that after we've defeated the monsters roaming our seas?
I'm sure we'll think of something. We've all been through too much to turn on each other after all of this.
There's still a war on. Once the truce is over, we'll all still be soldiers.

Fields.DialogueText: Fair enough, Captain - we'd best not drink our tea before the water boils.
That's my thought exactly, Captain. We'll take these monsters apart and fix everything, bingo bango bongo.
That's... true, Captain. Sorry to blag you for it.
Get your head together, Nellie. We've got a war to fight with these monsters before we can think about what happens after.
Don't worry, Captain. Fighting the monsters is what I'm bloody marvelous at.
@BATTLE
Am I seeing some new faces around here, Nellie? It looks like your decks are fuller than I last saw them.
Got it in one, Captain. It's nice to feel the decks stepping lively again.
Glad to see it, Nellie. Are the newcomers getting along well?
The old hands are chipping in to show them around, and I'm pointing them in the right direction when I need to.
A lot of them are babes in the woods, though. I'd rather they stop razzing on the decks and having it out with each other.
I suppose it's helpful to have the physical embodiment of the ship to show them around, isn't it?
I'm not a bloody tour guide, Captain. It's not my job to make sure they aren't bodging their duties.
Fair point.

Fields.MenuText: I suppose the only true test of their worth is the next battle, isn't it?
As long as the others chip in, I'm sure they'll put their backs into it when they need to.
They'll need to shape up fast, or they'll drag down the rest of the crew. We can't afford slackers.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sure they'll bash on when we go aggro, no matter how bleeding incompetent they may be.
They should be pulling their own bleeding weight, not freeloading off the old deckhands.
It's not often you get a blinding crew, so I'm not having kittens about it. As long as they don't leave everything higgledy-piggledy, we'll be shipshape.
Well, get them clean and dressed, we have a war to get back to.
Aye aye, Captain. Come on, you lot! It's not a bloody fair day! We've got a war to fight!
@BATTLE
They didn't do too badly out there, Captain. I'm genuinely impressed.
Well, I would hope the older sailors are pitching in to make sure the inexperienced ones are keeping their nerve.
That's not quite it. The old hands are minding the babes, of course, but a few of the new sailors are a bit on in years, and managed things well.
Oh, that's good to hear. I suppose you got a good batch, given your pride of place.
Well I am the grand dame of the fleet, after all. Perhaps I did have a jammy run.
I would take advantage of it. Pick the best of them and then promote them to a place of authority.
I think you're right. I still need to fill a few holes in the roster after that... after those battles.
I understand Nellie. But that's no reason to let things go slack.

Fields.MenuText: You can't let the past stop you from pressing forwards into the future.
That wasn't your fault, Nellie. Now get your ship back into proper fighting shape.
Now get over it and fill out your bridge crew. You need to get these fellows integrated properly.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, Captain. The past informs us, but it can't be what controls us.
Of course, Captain. It's just hard, replacing faces I used to know, and had come to trust.
Right away, Captain! I'll be back in fighting trim in no time. I'll not be the noddy ship in the fleet.
*ALARM*
Good to hear - now get ready. We have a pack of Morganas to destroy.
@BATTLE
Enjoying your downtime, Nellie? I see you're writing another letter. Is this one to Rodney again?
Actually, this one's to nowt other than the king himself! Thought I'd keep him apprised of the situation.
The king? George VI, *that* king?
Not very often - I don't know him that well. He was at my christening, though, and he is still my king.
Do you write to a lot of people, or just to family and select royals?
Mostly to Rodney, but there are a few others. I'll sometimes open a brown ale and tell the king - or an old officer - how the war is going.

Fields.MenuText: That's a nice thought, Nellie. I'm sure they look forward to the letters.
That seems like a waste of time. Are you sure you aren't just giving them more to worry about?
Do as you want, Nellie. Your free time is yours, after all.

Fields.DialogueText: I do hope so, Captain. I know I always appreciate their replies when I get them.
Of course not, Captain. They have a lot on their plates as it is, and I'm simply letting them know I'm safe and sound.
Good of you to say. I try to pinch a few minutes here and there to make sure I can find the time.
Well and good, Nellie - but I did want to tell you that we've got a battle coming up soon.
Thanks, Captain. I'll make sure the tees are crossed and the eyes  dotted, and once the ink's dry, we'll show the BF what for.
@BATTLE
... I would say I don't use the same kind of language for both, but that would be a damn lie.
I don't really have to pay attention to any other king, Captain.
Yeah, but... I mean, do you write him regularly?
So he is. Okay.
How are the new officers treating you, Nellie? Making a good impact on the crew?
I reckon they're doing a close enough job to right. One of them was plastered the first day, and a few are working through the lurgy.
Ah, I see. Any standouts on the other side of things? Anyone doing a good job keeping the new men in shape?
There are a few out there, beavering away. It's still full of divvies, to be sure, but they have what it takes. In fact, there's a stand-out there!
Evenin', Captain, Lady Nelson. Beggin' your leave, but we've got the guns swung stowed and the barrels locked, and we're ready to be underway.
That will be all, Bosun. Make sure the men are clear and the engine is warmed up, and then we're steaming out of here.
Aye aye, Lady Nelson!

Fields.MenuText: Well, he's an enthusiastic one at least. It looks like he's on top of things.
He seems a bit too excited to me. I think you have a fan in him.
It's nice to see you have a few crewmen who are settling in so well. I hope the rest take after him.

Fields.DialogueText: Indeed, he's been quite a lot of help to me, and he's learning the ropes very quickly.
Who doesn't love big guns on a beauty like me, hmm Captain?
He's been an inspiration to the ones still running about like idgits, making a dog's breakfast of everything.
We'll have to see how he fares when the fights come fast and thick, shall we?
@BATTLE
Anything else you need, ma'am? I've got the men reloading from the stores.
No, not with that. I think we'll be shipshape in Bristol fashion again.
Aye Aye, Lady Nelson. I'll see to the disposition of the men then.
Well, isn't he a hard worker? It's nice to see how well he's gotten the crew together.
I know, isn't he? Jammy to have him around, innit? A spot of luck for all of us, really.
And he hasn't lost his nerve against the Morganas, which is impressive in and of itself.
More than a few razzed over the bows after that first fight, didn't they? Still, we're fit as a fiddle lately.

Fields.MenuText: Regardless, how are you holding up? Your tactics are working, and your crew is solid.
Don't get too cocky, you never know when the Morganas will pull a new trick out of their deck.
That is good to hear. I'm glad to know the fleet is in fighting shape.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, I know, but it doesn't do to get cocky when we haven't yet put paid to the BF.
I know, I won't. Whatever the BF throws at us, we'll be ready to catch it.
Always, Captain. Your Nelson will be steaming through the battle, even if the decks are full of water and the holds empty.
Good to hear it, Nelson. Now let's get back to that war of ours.
@BATTLE
Hello, Nellie - what's that you have there? Writing another letter?
Receiving, not writing, Captain. This is post from King George himself, thanking me for remembering him and such.
He actually wrote back? I wouldn't have thought he had the time.
Ah, but I'm an excellent pen pal. Definitely worth a few hours' investment.
Well, you have me there. So, what does His Majesty write you about? The war at home?
Ah, Captain. You know better than to ask a Lady about her personals, don't you?
I... actually don't think I want to know how personal you get with the King of England. I think I'll let you read it in peace.
Oh, don't be like that, Captain. He writes me on all manner of things, we're both rather old hands at tough times after all.

Fields.MenuText: Who else writes you letters? I've seen your correspondence going out, but not as much coming in.
I still think writing these letters is a waste of time, when you could be drilling the fleet.
I'm glad to know that your relationships with your pen pals isn't entirely one-sided.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, all manner of folk. From my sister, to my cousins in the fleet, to the folks back home, to old crew, to barmy fools gone soppy with talk of the Belles.
Yes, and it's it just a right shame that you don't have any say in what I do with my time, hmm?
Oh, I get any number of letters, and some of them I even wish to receive. It's rather easy for barmpots to get your address when it's a ship.
I suppose that makes a certain amount of sense. Get ready for combat when you finish - we've got Morganas on the horizon.
Perfect. That'll give me something else to write home about.
@BATTLE
I think we have a good chance of surprising them here. The strait should keep them contained enough for us to do a fair amount of damage.
I think you're on the right track, Captain. We can bottle them up and hit them hard, and then get out before the fight turns into a slog.
My thoughts exactly. Now we just need to work on disposition of the forces.
Lady Nelson, the chef thought you might like a slice of cherry pie. It's quite fresh.
Thank you, Bosun.
Of course, Lady Nelson. I am, as ever, at your service.
Bloody useful, that man. Always seems to turn up where he's needed, I have to say. He's never in one place for long.

Fields.MenuText: He's settling in very well for a new addition to the crew, isn't he?
He seems eager to please, which isn't always a bad thing.
As long as he doesn't overstep his bounds. Try not to spill that on the map, by the way.

Fields.DialogueText: Indeed, and he's a very good example to the rest of the crew of what they can do if they put their nose to the grindstone.
No, no it isn't. It  brought me fresh pie after all.
I would never! Spilled pie doesn't go in my mouth, and such things are a travesty.
Very well. Now finish your pie and we'll see to the disposition of the ships. We have a war to fight.
@BATTLE
Captain, do you remember life before the war? Back when everything was so much simpler?
I think you might have had enough brown ale for the evening, Nellie.
No, I mean it. Everything made sense, and I was proud to show the Union Jack at every port we called at. And now, things are changing.
We're fighting monsters nowt ever envisioned and sailing with a bloody great fleet from all over the bloody world. It's not anything I ever suspected I would see.

Fields.MenuText: To be fair, I never thought I'd be having this conversation with a friend of mine who was also a ship.
I've seen too much war, of this one and others, to really remember what the world was like beforehand.
Don't worry, Nellie - we'll sort this business out soon enough, and then we'll get the world back on track.

Fields.DialogueText: Pillock. Are you saying people can't be friends with ships?
That's... a bit grim, Captain. You should have something in your life aside from war.
I can't help but believe you when you say it that way, Captain. I know we can do this together.
You've got me there, Nellie. Now, let's clear up these bottles - we've got a war to win.
Aye Aye, Captain! Let's give the BF what for!
@BATTLE
Wotcher, Captain! Have you seen Bosun Hardy today? I can't seem to find him anywhere.
I haven't. I assume he's just keeping busy today - that's pretty normal for him.
Yes, it's true. But I can't find him anywhere, and this isn't the first time he's been scarce.
I hadn't noticed that. And you don't think he's just reading old newspapers in the head?
I don't. If he was onboard, I should be able to find him if I look. He only gets hard to find when we're near the coast, as well.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe he has a girl, and he's sneaking off to see her.
Okay. This is starting to sound like a security risk.
I'm sure he's around here somewhere, maybe he's just naturally hard to find.

Fields.DialogueText: She'd have to be aboard one of the other ships in the fleet, or he'd have to have more than a few girls.
Oh, I don't think he's a Morgana saboteur or anything. Still, it is rather strange.
That's fair, usually I have much better luck spotting him when some of the rest of the crew is with him.
*ALARM*
Either way, we're just going to have to beat this next batch of Morganas without him.
We've done it a few times before. We aren't complete wasters without one crewman.
@BATTLE
Finished with your prayers? Mind if I come in?
Of course not, come on in. I'm just finishing up another letter.
Oh? And who is the recipient of Lady Nelson's correspondence this time? His Majesty again? Your sister?
No, this one is to you. It's to help address occasional bouts of gormlessness and help you remember the bright parts of these somewhat dim days.
My thanks, Nellie. That's very nice of you.

Fields.MenuText: I suppose letters are a great method for keeping a record, aren't they? I hadn't thought of that.
I'm not sure I'll need it. This war is etching itself into my memory with every cannon shot.
I'd just as soon forget most of what we've seen and done.

Fields.DialogueText: I am nothing if not a font of wisdom, Captain. You'll be sure to remember that when you look back on your bundle of post.
I want you to remember more than just the battles, Captain. We need to capture the nobility, the sacrifice, and the brilliance of the people around us.
I understand the sentiment Captain, really I do. But the BF win if we let them push the sun from our sky.
I believe you, Nellie. Thank you, truly. I can't wait to read it.
*ALARM*
Well, that's the alarm. It looks like you'll have to practice patience a moment longer.
@BATTLE
"Occasional bouts of gormlessness?"
I thought it was excessive to say "regular."
It's official, Captain - Bosun Hardy is absent without leave. What could he possibly be thinking?
I'm not sure, but he clearly has priorities beyond helping the fleet. How do you know he's missing?
The last time anyone remembers seeing him, he was taking headcount after a battle. And then, nothing.
Would you have sensed it if he'd gone overboard?
Oh, I hear it when a member of my crew is in trouble. This is something much dodgier, and I won't stand for it on my ship.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe he deserted? It's possible the stress broke him, and he couldn't take the war anymore.
I assume you talked to all the sailors to see if they remember anything.
I wouldn't worry about him. If he turns up, we'll deal with him. Otherwise, we have a war to fight.

Fields.DialogueText: I can't see him doing that. He loved the fleet and England too much to do a runner on us.
Of course, but none of them seem to be able to come up with an idea that isn't just about him being a bit of a tyke.
That's as it is I suppose. Nothing to be done without the man himself here to question.
*ALARM*
Just put him out of your mind for now - I need you focused.
Of course, Captain. We'll take the BF apart out there.
@BATTLE
Thank you for your understanding, Lady Nelson. I knew you would understand how important family is to an Englishman.
Of course, Bosun. Now get out of here. The Captain and I have much to discuss.
My apologies for troubling you with this, Lady Nelson, Captain. I assure you it will not happen again.
Captain, I'm interested in hearing your opinion on what I should do about this little problem.

Fields.MenuText: I can't fault a man for his dedication to his family. As long as the problem is resolved, it shouldn't be an issue going forward.
I don't care why he deserted his port - assuming he's telling the truth. He deserted his post.
He's your crewman, and the manner you choose to remonstrate with him is beyond the wealth of my advice.

Fields.DialogueText: True, but someone who has left their post without orders, and without discussion, cannot be abided.
True, his lack of duty to God and country is a great insult, and deserves harsh consequences.
I didn't think I'd see you abdicating responsibility in such a matter, Captain, but I see your point.
It's all a rather moot point, though, because he was lying through his teeth.
The possibility had occurred to me.
After we clear the BF from this sector, we'll clear the air about him.
@BATTLE
Bosun Hardy, front and center! And no excuses.
Is something the matter, Lady Nelson?
You're blooming right, something's the matter. I want to know what's so important you'd jeopardize yourself, this ship, and my crew.
I already told you, Lady Nelson, my cousins have been–
Don't lie to me, you pustulent boil. I know all the Hardys from Sir Thomas on down, and you said half their names wrong - not to mention none have ever mentioned you!
Crikey! We never thought you'd twig on about that! Oooh, I should not have said that.

Fields.MenuText: We need to find out who he is working for and if he put the fleet in danger in any way.
Whatever you want to do to this man, you have my support Nelson.
Who would have thought we'd have a spy in our midst?

Fields.DialogueText: Right you are Captain. Well, "Hardy", who put you up to this?
Good, I was thinking about keelhauling the blaggard myself, but I'd rather know why he did it.
It's almost like the fleet was supposed to be owt working together. I wonder which berk decided that wasn't good enough.
I'm sorry Lady Nelson, I can't tell you the details of my mission.
*ALARM*
Then I reckon you're going to the brig. Men! Take this simpering excrescence out of here - we have a war to fight!
@BATTLE
How are you holding up, Nellie? You've seemed a bit more... intense than usual lately.
Can you blame me? After Hardy? We look like a right pair of plonkers.
I understand, but you can't let what happened get in the way of our duties to each other out here.
You don't have to tell me my duty, Captain. I'm not the one spying on my mates for God knows who.
That's fair.

Fields.MenuText: Would it help if I let you run a nice firing drill on your cannons? I think we can spare the ammunition.
I can have the chef whip up a nice pan haggerty and we can take some leisure time to read.
Do you think it would help you if you went and talked to the chaplain?

Fields.DialogueText: I do like firing my lovely cannons... If you're sure we can spare it, I'd love to give them a good sounding.
Don't try to buy my happiness with food, Captain. Although, a quiet evening with a friend and some good food does sound nice.
He won't tell me anything I don't already know, but I guess it would be nice to talk through this with someone else.
*ALARM*
I'll have to put it on hold for a bit, though. That sounds like the alarm.
@BATTLE
Hey, Nellie - you're looking a little happier. Who's this letter going to?
This one's to King George, actually. I'd like to hear his opinion on things.
I'm not sure how I feel about airing our dirty laundry with Buckingham Palace, frankly.
Granted - but you aren't His Majesty's premier battleship, with a top of the line array of nine 16 inch gun mounts.
Heh. Thank you for reminding me.

Fields.MenuText: What kind of advice are you expecting to hear back?
I suppose there might be some value in an outside perspective.
Still, I'd suggest that you don't include any details you're not comfortable having an army of censors and analysts raking over with a fine-tooth comb.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I'm not asking him for advice, exactly. He's the sovereign; his opinion on what should be done about this is going to inform the official policy.
Actually, I was thinking it could be of value to him as well. I don't reckon he hears much about quotidian life on his ships from his ministers.
No worries, Captain. I wasn't launched yesterday.
Ah, my mistake. Well, let's hope for a speedy and helpful response, shall we?
Indeed. Let me wait for this ink to dry, and I'll swing the ship around, We have a BF to rout, after all.
Right you are Nellie, I'll go get the fleet ready to engage.
@BATTLE
I suppose I'm just more secure in my performance than you are, then.
Okay, let me just remind you that we're literally in the same boat here.
Hah! The cheek on this bugger, asking to be let out of the brig.
I assume he still hasn't revealed who he's been reporting to?
... But he is an asset to the smooth running of the ship. Or at least he was.
Please don't tell me you're playing the "Belle intuition" card.
I'm not sure what I believe. He's got me convinced he's an Englishman true, but we need to be better than that in the fleet.

Fields.MenuText: You're right. We can't let regional differences drive us apart out here. We all have to watch each other's backs.
How did he convince you? Complain about the rain while otherwise keeping a stiff upper lip.
I say leave him in the brig until he sings regardless.

Fields.DialogueText: All too true. And I'm not sure he understands that.
Hah, don't be a git. But yes, something like that. He's definitely firmly in the King's corner.
You're not wrong, but I did like having a pet to run down to the wardroom when fresh pie was on the offing.
Either way... well, if I do recommend letting him out, it would only be under intense guard.
Well, you'll have to think about it during the fight. Get the crew ready, we're hitting the enemy in an hour.
@BATTLE
Pardon?
I'm willing to believe you know more about the crew than I do. If you tell me you believe he's not a risk, I'd have to at least consider it.
Despite the fact that he is *clearly* a security risk.
Heh.
Nelson, I need to talk to you about the last few battles.
Is there something wrong? Our tactics haven't started failing again, have they?
No, of course not. But I'm getting a little bit worried about you.
Whyever for, Captain? I'm just doing my best to hound the BF out of every squalid little bay and inlet that might offer them shelter.
That's my point, Nellie. You're being reckless, and I'm worried you're going to pay for it soon. You can't let anger be what drives you.
The thing is, I'm nearly always angry, Captain. I'm just grateful I have a productive way to work it off.

Fields.MenuText: Be that as it may, I want you to watch yourself out there. You are too important to myself and this fleet to be lost recklessly.
... Fair point. I'd rather see your anger vented on those monsters than anywhere else.
You aren't always this uninhibited, though. You damn near rammed that last Morgana.

Fields.DialogueText: Aye aye, Captain... I'm sorry, I'm bloody cross, and putting it ahead of my duty. I'll try to rein it in.
That's the ticket, Captain. I'll try to be more careful, though. I don't know what you'd do without me.
Can you imagine the look on that monster's face? But I see your point. I'll be a spot more careful.
*ALARM*
That's all I can ask, Nellie. Now, let's go show those monsters what for.
I thought you'd never ask, Captain. For God and country!
@BATTLE
Now see to the disposition of the men, and make sure the cannons are primed and ready.
Yes, Lady Nelson. Any other tasks for me?
No, now get out of my sight. And guards, if he gives you any trouble, he can swim home.
I see the Bosun talked his way out of the brig.
Well, we don't have enough food on the ship for a man in limbo. It takes fewer lads to watch him out here than to mind his cell.
I'm not sure how the math works on that one, but I'll take your word for it.
Well, if the brig is occupied, we need a watch officer for it, and a minder, and–
No, Nellie, I believe you, it's all right. How are the crew dealing with having him about?
They think he's lying about what he did, but they reckon it was just a matter of sneaking off to see a girl or something. Professionally, they trust his judgment, so it's a net positive.

Fields.MenuText: As long as he's well guarded, I suppose I don't see the harm.
At least this gives us a chance to monitor him and figure out what he's up to. But we need to watch him like hawks.
I don't like it. He's not one of us, whatever and whomever he might be.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, that's why I have a nice batch of Royal Marines, innit?
I will - and so will our Royal Marines. Those boys, at least, we can be sure of.
I don't particularly like it either, but it's better than the alternative. If he's sowing sedition, I'll soon hear of it.
That makes sense. And it is your ship, after all. Now let's get ready, we've had Morgana sightings.
@BATTLE
That blaggard! That bloody todger! That absolute poxy git! I cannot believe this!
What is it, Nellie? Is Hardy acting up again?
No! Yes! Gah, blimey, it's not him, it's His Highness! Look at this letter! He said the little prat's on our ship on purpose!
You mean Hardy is a spy for England? Why?
It's all here! He was trying to keep an eye on the fleet, and he was sneaking onto land to do God knows what in the war there!
You mean the British government knowingly sent someone onto this ship to violate the Neutrality...
I... think we should probably keep it quiet, Captain. We don't gain anything by making the crew think the brass doesn't trust us.

Fields.MenuText: I understand. This would put a lot strain on all of us if it got out.
My lips are sealed. But I trust you'll use your preferred back channels to make our displeasure known back in London.
I can't believe that they'd betray our trust like that. What is going on in their war that they're hurting ours this way?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad you see what I mean Captain. Don't worry, I'll make sure that this is resolved.
You better believe that a whole host of someones is going to get a bleeding earful from me!
I don't know, but I suppose they're starting to get more than a little worried about whatever it is. Don't worry, though, I'll deal with it.
Good. Don't be particularly gentle about it.
@BATTLE
No, he's not a commando or anything. I reckon he's just another political officer - just one we weren't supposed to know about.
Get out of my sight and get back to your duties, you little blighter. We have a war to fight.
Of course, Lady Nelson. But, if I may be so bold, might–
You may not! Now get back to your station before I have you towed there!
Aye aye, Lady Nelson.
It seems like he's still a bit of a raw wound for you, Nellie.
Yes, and I feel off my rocker for letting him stay - but I'd rather have him inside pissing out than outside pissing in.
Heh.

Fields.MenuText: I think it shows a lot of heart that you're letting him stay aboard.
I can't believe you didn't just toss him overboard and let the sharks and Morganas sort him out.
I'm impressed with the amount of patience you've shown through this whole mess.

Fields.DialogueText: Hah, maybe it shows that I'm a pillock. But he seems to have been on his best behavior so far.
Trust me, I considered it. I'd have liked to put him in the grinder feet first, but he was just doing his duty.
Thank you, Captain. It's been hard not to scream him senseless whenever I see him, but I think this is the best choice.
*ALARM*
As long as he doesn't let us down under fire, I suppose...
@BATTLE
Captain, come in here with me for a minute - I've got a hot pan haggerty and some brown ales tucked away.
Of course, Nellie. What's the occasion?
Nothing special, Captain. I just needed a small moment of... stability, I suppose.
Stability might be a bit much to hope for, but let's give it a shot.
Cor, I knew you'd be the one for the job, Captain. Care for a bit of a flutter?
Did you just challenge me to a game of chance? What's the game?
Crown and Anchor. What're the stakes?

Fields.MenuText: The rest of the pan haggerty, and the loser's drink rations for the week.
Loser has to wear a silly hat tomorrow and not acknowledge it no matter what anyone says.
Loser has to write the winner a letter formally declaring them their tactical superior.

Fields.DialogueText: Blimey, you're a mean one. I suppose I'll have to take you down hard.
It can't be any sillier than the one's I've already seen you wear, Captain.
Hah, I can't have that. I already know you're not anywhere near my level.
All right, you're on. The loser can take out their frustrations on the BF.
@BATTLE
All right, Bosun, you have your orders. Now go carry them out.
By your leave, Lady Nelson. It is my honour.
Yes, yes - now get out of here.
I swear, Captain - he'll be the death of me one way or the other.
It seems like you've gotten a bit nicer to him in the past few days. Am I wrong?
Well spotted, Captain. He hasn't made a fuss, and he's been working hard for the crew.
Hrm.

Fields.MenuText: What do you think about the surveillance operation, now that you've had some time?
It's honestly not the most egregious case I've heard of, to be honest. At least this guy is competent.
I'm not sure how long it'll be before we have another incident like this, though.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't like it. I understand it, but I don't like it. And I won't have it on my ship, or any ship in the fleet.
Well, if he wasn't earning his keep, I'd just get him transferred onto a French ship. Heh.
It might be a good idea to let everyone know what happened discreetly, at least the other Belles. They'd want to know if it happened to them.
*ALARM*
Hey, did we ever find out his real name?
@BATTLE
One thing at a time, Captain.
Nelson, what are you doing down here in the lower decks?
I could ask you the same question, couldn't I? I heard something down here.
I was getting similar reports, and thought I'd take a look around.
Do you hear it? It's coming from down past the ammo stores.
Sir, I think I've gained their trust. We should be near the coast again soon, and I can slip away for a lookabout.
Hardy, you gobshite! Have you got a radio down here? Are you still reporting on us?!
I had to, Lady Nelson! England must be protected!
We are protecting her, you daft berk! Marines, seize that dodgy git and throw him back in the brig!

Fields.MenuText: The brig? Not overboard this time?
Again, Hardy? What made you think we wouldn't catch you?
I'd say he could still be useful to us, but at this point I honestly think he's just too thick.

Fields.DialogueText: Believe me, I'm thinking about it. This prat's liable to get us all killed, and his radio might be bringing the BF even now.
The fact that he's an absolute prat.
Well, we're still going to be able to send a message with the little todger. This won't be tolerated.
*ALARM*
Bloody hell! That's the alarm. Drop him lads. Bosun, if you do your job well, maybe you'll live to see tomorrow.
@BATTLE
I wouldn't count on that.
All right, lads, you can let him go. Well, Bosun, what do you have to say for yourself?
I'm doing what needs to be done. The war is rough on all of us, and we need all the edges we can get in this dog's breakfast.
And you should be helping, all of you. This crew's English, by God, and we need to think about what will happen to England after.
So, you want me to be a nosey parker and poke into the rest of the fleet? For what, so we can get the jump on the rest of them when the BF are gone?
Not so crass as that, but yes. We need to be ready for when these blaggards turn on us.
You'll never understand the fleet. Get him out of my sight, lads. Toss him in the dinghy and shove him off - he can make his way home from port.

Fields.MenuText: That must have been hard, but I appreciate having you with us.
You know there's probably going to be more like him, right?
We're lucky to have you with us, Nellie. You're irreplaceable.

Fields.DialogueText: It was hard not to execute him outright. You're a jammy git to have me with you Captain, but I'm glad to be here.
Well, maybe the next one won't be stupid enough to practice spycraft with a radio where I can hear it. Britain used to have standards, for God's sake.
Bleeding right I am, Captain! Who else has my gun profile, eh? Tonne for tonne, I'm the best tactician and warship you have!
Well. Ready for the next round?
I can't believe you even needed to ask.
@BATTLE
I would find your argument more compelling if you'd managed to accomplish anything beyond undermining discipline on my ship.
Captain, I...
I'm past the point of desiring your opinion, Bosun.
